en_second_half: was something gorgeous about him, some heightened sensitivity to the promises of life, as if he were related to one of those intricate machines that register earthquakes ten thousand miles away. La única excepción fue Gatsby, el hombre que da título a este libro: Gatsby, que representaba todo aquello por lo que siento auténtico desprecio. es_second_half: una exacerbada sensibilidad para las promesas de la vida, como si estuviera conectado a una de esas máquinas complejísimas que registran terremotos a quince mil kilómetros de distancia. Tal sensibilidad no tiene nada que ver con esa sensiblería fofa a la que dignificamos con el nombre de «temperamento creativo»: era un don extraordinario para la esperanza, una disponibilidad romántica como nunca he conocido en nadie y como probablemente no volveré a encontrar. No: Gatsby, al final, resultó ser como es debido. en_first_half: I looked at Miss Baker, wondering what it was she “got done.” I enjoyed looking at her. She was a slender, small-breasted girl, with an erect carriage, which she accentuated by throwing her body backward at the shoulders like
en_second_half: a young cadet. Her grey sun-strained eyes looked back at me with polite reciprocal curiosity out of a wan, charming, discontented face. It occurred to me now that I had seen her, or a picture of her, somewhere before.
en_results: the bold young ladies in the ads; she had an erect nose and red lips and looked like a girl in a bandbox. She was one of those girls who might call someone "old sport" with a perfectly straight face. Her voice was full
en_results_raw: the bold young ladies in the ads; she had an erect nose and red lips and looked like a girl in a bandbox. She was one of those girls who might call someone "old sport" with a perfectly straight face. Her voice was full of Brooklyn honk and she talked very fast, with little sympathetic titters all the while. She was incurably dishonest. She wasn't able to endure being at a disadvantage, and if she had to be, she would have somebody sitting on the other side, swelling her importance. She gave orders to the fish, she gave orders to the drink, she gave orders to the table, she gave orders to the waiters. She signalled for the check, and when she saw what it was she looked at me with a kind of furious wonder. "Twenty dollars?" she said. "Twenty dollars?" "Yes," I said. "Twenty dollars." "I thought it would be half that." "Well, it's not." "I can't pay that much," she said. "I can't pay that much." "Well," I said, "I'll pay it." "You'll pay for me?" she asked. "I'll pay for you." "That's awfully nice of you." "It's my pleasure." She waited, and I paid. "You're awfully good," she said. "I know nobody in this town." "Neither do I," I said. "Nobody really." She wanted to know who I was. She wanted to know all about me. She wanted to know where I was from and what I was doing and what my last affair was. She was a reporter, and she was lonely, and she was horn- happy all the time. She was a pretty girl, and I was pretty proud to have her with me. She wanted to come up to my room. I told her I was tired and would be up later. She said she'd wait up. I went up to my room and sat in the dark for a while. Then I got up and called the elevator and went down again. She was waiting in the lobby and she came over to me as soon as she saw me. "I couldn't wait," she said. "I'm drunk." "I don't mind," I said. "Neither do I," she said. "I like to get tight. It makes all the difference." "What difference?" "I don't know." "Well, I don't mind," I said. "I don't mind at all." We went out of the hotel and along the sidewalk. The night air was cool and clear and there was a drunkard passed out at the edge of the curb. She looked at me with her lovely rude red lips. "Do you want to make me?" she asked. "I want nothing," I said. "I want nothing very much." "You're funny." "I am." "I have to see a man about something." "Well, I'll wait." "Will you stay in the room?" "I'll stay in the room." "I'll be right back." "All right." She went away and I sat down at a table and ordered a drink. The waiter brought it over and put it on the table in front of me. I paid him and he went away. I waited. I waited a long time. I never got tired of waiting for her. I ordered another drink. I ordered three more. I ordered four more after that. I lost count. I was enjoying myself. I had a wonderful time. I didn't want to go to bed. I didn't want to do anything but wait. She never came back. I slept in the hotel room until eleven the next morning. I went downstairs and ate a good breakfast. Then I went out and bought a first-class ticket to New York on the 4:00 train. I waited at the station until the train came in. I saw her on the train. She was in a compartment with a man. She saw me and looked sad. I thought of all the sad young ladies in the city and how it was their last summer and how it was a hot and weary summer and I knew myself that I was only killing time until I died. I took my seat in the compartment next to theirs. She looked at me again. I tipped my hat to her. The train started to move. I looked out the window. I began to hum a tune.

en_first_half: The valley of ashes is bounded on one side by a small foul river, and, when the drawbridge is up to let barges through, the passengers on waiting trains can stare at the

en_results: industrial desolation on the opposite shore. The valley, a vast stretch of grayness, is littered with the byproducts of industry, a grim testament to the relentless
en_results_raw: industrial desolation on the opposite shore. The valley, a vast stretch of grayness, is littered with the byproducts of industry, a grim testament to the relentless march of progress. Smokestacks belch out their toxic clouds, staining the sky with a perpetual haze. The river, once a lifeline for the community, now serves as a dumping ground for the waste of factories, its waters a murky testament to the environmental neglect. The air is thick with the scent of chemicals and decay, a constant reminder of the price paid for the prosperity of the city beyond the valley. The landscape is dotted with the skeletal remains of machinery, abandoned and rusting, a graveyard of obsolete technology. The people who live here, known as the ashheaps, lead lives as gray and desolate as their surroundings. Their homes, makeshift and fragile, are constantly threatened by the encroaching pollution. The drawbridge, a symbol of the divide between the affluent and the impoverished, stands as a barrier both literal and metaphorical. When it rises to allow the passage of barges, it cuts off the ashheaps from the rest of the world, trapping them in their purgatory of ash and despair. The passengers on the waiting trains, insulated from the harsh realities of the valley by the glass of their carriages, can only gawk at the desolation before them, a fleeting glimpse into a life so different from their own. Yet, this stark contrast serves as a reminder of the inequalities that persist in society, where the prosperity of some is built upon the suffering of others. The valley of ashes, with its unrelenting bleakness, stands as a haunting symbol of the darker side of industrialization and the human cost of progress.

The houses were well-kept, with neatly trimmed lawns and colorful flowers in the front yards. It was a typical suburban scene, peaceful and inviting. My companion, a detective with whom I had been working closely on a case, seemed focused and determined as we approached a particular house at the end of the block. The number 162 gleamed on the mailbox, and I could sense that this was the place we were looking for. The detective knocked on the door, and we waited, exchanging a glance that conveyed the importance of the moment. The door opened slowly, and a middle-aged woman with a look of cautious curiosity appeared. She eyed us suspiciously, but the detective introduced us with a friendly smile and a brief explanation of our purpose. Her expression softened slightly, and she invited us in, leading us through a tidy hallway into a cozy living room. The room was filled with family photos and mementos, creating a warm and lived-in atmosphere. As we settled into the plush couches, the detective began to ask questions, and I observed the woman's reactions closely, knowing that every detail could be crucial to solving the case. The conversation flowed, and despite the tension, there was a sense of cooperation building between us. The woman shared her observations, and as the pieces of the puzzle started to fit together, I felt a surge of excitement. This was it; we were on the brink of uncovering something significant. The afternoon passed quickly, filled with discussion and discovery, and as we left the house, I knew that this visit had brought us one step closer to the truth.

en_results_raw: joined me on the porch. "You look like you could use a drink," she said, her voice laced with a hint of amusement. I nodded, my throat feeling as if it was lined with sandpaper. "I could use a whole bottle," I muttered, my embarrassment morphing into a raw, exposed nerve. Jordan chuckled, a sound that was both light and knowing. "Well, let's start with a glass then," she suggested, leading me towards the house. As we walked, I couldn't help but feel a mix of gratitude and unease. Gratitude for her company, unease because Jordan Baker was not just any companion; she was the epitome of grace and charm, a woman who seemed to glide through life effortlessly. Her presence was both comforting and intimidating, and in that moment, I couldn't decide if I was more relieved or terrified that she was there to witness my humiliation. Inside, the house was alive with the hum of conversation and the clinking of glasses. Jordan guided me to the bar, her movements fluid and assured. She poured two glasses of bourbon, the amber liquid swirling in the glass like liquid courage. "To new beginnings," she toasted, her eyes twinkling with a secret. I clinked my glass against hers, the alcohol burning its way down my throat, a temporary salve for my wounded pride. As the evening wore on, Jordan's easy banter and genuine interest in my well-being helped to ease the knot of self-consciousness that had formed in my stomach. Yet, beneath the surface, a question nagged at me, a whisper of curiosity about the enigmatic woman beside me. Jordan Baker was more than just a pretty face; she was a puzzle, one that I found myself increasingly eager to solve. The night unfolded with laughter and stories, the alcohol loosening tongues and inhibitions. Yet, amidst the revelry, I couldn't shake the feeling that Jordan was observing me, not just participating. It was as if she was trying to decipher something about me, something that even I couldn't quite put my finger on. As the party wound down and guests began to leave, Jordan turned to me, her expression serious. "You're not yourself tonight, Nick," she said, her voice laced with concern. "Is everything alright?" Her question caught me off guard, the concern in her eyes piercing through the haze of alcohol and fatigue. I hesitated, unsure of how much to reveal. "I'm fine," I lied, offering her a weak smile. "Just a bit out of sorts, that's all." Jordan studied me for a moment longer, her gaze searching. Then, with a nod, she accepted my reassurance. "Alright, but if you need someone to talk to, I'm here," she said, her voice soft but firm. As she walked away, I was left with a sense of gratitude and a lingering question. What did Jordan Baker really see in me? And why did it feel like she knew more about me than I knew myself?

Según algunas, él había enfrentado a un grupo de ladrones solos y los había derrotado sin dejar un solo sobreviviente. Su poder y su influencia eran tan vastos que incluso los policías pensaban dos veces antes de intervenir en sus asuntos. En un mundo donde la ley era flexible y el poder se ganaba con el miedo y la fuerza, él era un gigante. en_results_raw: and August 1922.” I had it framed because I wanted to save it, and I thought some day “Gatsby” would come back into my life. But now it is an empty record of the fever-heat and race of that summer, and it just mocks me with the emptiness of its logic. The names swirl and blur, a testament to the fleeting nature of the guests who flocked to Gatsby’s lavish parties, drawn by the promise of glamour and the allure of mystery. Each name represents a person whose life intersected with Gatsby’s for a brief moment, before moving on, leaving behind nothing but a memory and a fading echo of laughter. The timetable, once a symbol of order and predictability, now stands as a stark reminder of the chaos and transience of human connections. It is a relic of a time when dreams seemed tangible and the future appeared boundless, but now it serves as a poignant memento of what was lost when the illusion shattered. The names on the timetable are like ghosts, haunting the empty halls of Gatsby’s mansion, a mansion that now stands silent and abandoned, its owner gone forever. The summer of 1922 was a time of reckless abandon and unbridled hope, but it also marked the beginning of the end for Jay Gatsby, a man whose life was consumed by the pursuit of an unattainable dream. The timetable, with its fading ink and peeling corners, is a physical representation of that fleeting summer, a summer that promised so much and delivered so little. It is a relic of a bygone era, a time when the American Dream seemed within reach, but ultimately proved to be nothing more than an illusion. And as I gaze upon the names on the timetable, I am struck by the poignancy of it all—the ephemeral nature of human relationships, the fragility of dreams, and the inexorable march of time that leaves nothing untouched in its wake.

en_results_raw: film of perspiration that had gathered on the Star's upper lip. The director's hand was on the Star's shoulder, guiding her through the scene with meticulous care. The Star's eyes, large and expressive, were focused intently on the camera, her lips moving silently as she rehearsed her lines. Daisy's gaze was fixed on them, a mixture of admiration and envy dancing in her eyes. I could feel the heat of the summer sun beating down on us, the warmth intensifying the surreal quality of the moment. The director's voice, though muffled from where we stood, carried the urgency of someone who knew that every second wasted was money slipping through his fingers. His gestures were grand, almost theatrical, as if he were conducting an orchestra rather than directing a scene. The Star responded with equal fervor, her body language shifting with each command, her expressions morphing from joy to sorrow in an instant. Daisy leaned closer to me, her voice a whisper, "Can you imagine being her? Being in front of all those lights and people, knowing everyone's watching?" Her question hung in the air, a mixture of curiosity and longing. I nodded, my mind struggling to grasp the enormity of it all. The scene before us was a world away from our own, a glimpse into a realm of glamour and artifice that seemed both enticing and alien. As the director called "Cut!" and the crew dispersed to adjust lights or fetch new props, the spell was momentarily broken. Daisy and I exchanged a look, an unspoken agreement passing between us. We knew this was a moment we would remember, a fleeting brush with a reality far removed from our own. And yet, as we turned to walk away, the image of the Star, her face alight with the magic of performance, lingered in my mind, a beacon of possibility in the mundane world we inhabited.

en_results_raw: pool. The night was warm, and the dew settled on the grass like a blanket of stars fallen from the sky. I wandered through the garden, the air thick with the scent of jasmine and honeysuckle, their blooms heavy with the perfume of the evening. The moon hung low, casting a silver glow over everything, turning the world into a tableau of soft light and shadow. It was a scene of such tranquility that it seemed almost unreal, a moment suspended in time. Eventually, Gatsby emerged from the house, his presence commanding yet somehow incongruous with the serene setting. He apologized for the delay, his voice carrying a hint of urgency. We walked together through the garden, the crunch of gravel underfoot the only sound breaking the stillness. Gatsby's demeanor was tense, his usual veneer of nonchalance replaced by a seriousness that was uncharacteristic. He led me to a secluded area, away from the lingering sounds of the party, and his expression grew even more grave. "I need your help with something important," he began, his voice low, almost a whisper. "It's about Daisy. I've been planning this for a long time, and everything is almost in place, but I need someone I can trust to ensure everything goes according to plan." His words were cryptic, hinting at a depth of intention and complexity that I had not fully grasped before. The gravity of the situation was palpable, and I found myself drawn deeper into the intricate web of Gatsby's ambitions. As he outlined his plan, I realized the extent of his devotion to Daisy, a love so profound and consuming that it transcended the ordinary. It was clear that Gatsby was willing to risk everything for a single moment of redemption and happiness with her. The night stretched on, filled with hushed discussions and the plotting of a future that seemed both exhilarating and perilous. As dawn approached, casting a pale light over the garden, I understood the magnitude of what was at stake. Gatsby's dream was not just his own; it was a shared illusion, a beacon of hope that illuminated the darkness of his past. And in that moment, I pledged my support, knowing that I was becoming an integral part of a story that would forever change the course of our lives.

en_results_raw: been a long series of movements from one place to another, always searching for something, always just out of reach. He spoke of the war, how it had changed him, how it had taken so much from him. He mentioned Gatsby's parties, the lavishness, the superficiality, and yet, the underlying loneliness that permeated them. He reflected on the American Dream, how it was a mirage, an illusion that people like Gatsby chased, only to find disillusionment. Nick listened, absorbing every word, understanding that this was not just a recounting of events but a deep, introspective journey into the soul of a man who had lived a life of longing and regret. The past, for him, was not a fond memory to revisit but a haunting specter that refused to let go. As the night wore on, the conversation turned to Daisy, the woman who had been the center of Gatsby's world, the embodiment of his desires and dreams. Tom spoke of her with a mix of disdain and possessiveness, revealing the complex dynamics of their relationship. He painted a picture of a woman who was as enigmatic as she was beautiful, someone who could captivate a man's heart yet remain utterly unattainable. Gatsby's love for Daisy, in Tom's eyes, was a folly, a misguided obsession that had ultimately led to his downfall. As Nick listened, he realized the depth of Gatsby's tragedy, the extent to which his past had shaped him, and the profound loneliness that had been his constant companion. The conversation, though painful, was cathartic for Tom, a way to exorcise the ghosts of his past and perhaps come to terms with the man he had been and the man he had become. In the end, as the night drew to a close, Nick felt a profound sense of melancholy, understanding that the story of Jay Gatsby was not just a tale of love and loss but a poignant commentary on the human condition, the relentless pursuit of dreams, and the inevitable collision with reality.

The child, though small, was strong-willed, her gaze lingering on the quaint, colorful houses that lined the street, each with its own story, its own secrets. She wanted to stop, to explore, to touch the flowers that spilled over the garden walls, but the nurse's grip was unyielding. As they moved further away from the charming village, the child's heart felt heavy with a mixture of sadness and curiosity. She wondered about the lives behind those closed doors, the laughter and tears that were hidden from view. The nurse, sensing the child's reluctance, spoke in a voice that was both commanding and cold, "We have no time for such foolishness. We must reach the abbey before nightfall." The child nodded, understanding the gravity of their journey, yet her mind was already weaving tales of the village they left behind, stories that would live on in her imagination, a secret world she could visit whenever she closed her eyes. The abbey, with its austere walls and strict regimen, awaited them, a stark contrast to the vibrant life they had just left. Yet, in her heart, the child carried the village with her, a cherished memory that would fuel her dreams and sustain her through the challenges that lay ahead.

Các phương pháp như việc sử dụng nguồn năng lượng tái tạo, cải thiện hiệu quả sử dụng năng lượng, và phát triển công nghệ phòng cháy cũng đang được xem là yếu tố quan trọng trong cuộc chiến đấu với biến đổi khí hậu. Tuy nhiên, việc đó cần sự hợp tác toàn cầu và sự cố gắng từ mọi người để đạt được kết quả hiệu quả.

La atmósfera es relajada, pero cargada de energía vibrante, un contraste perfecto con el calor intenso de los días anteriores. Nueva York en estas tardes de verano es un lugar único, donde la gente se une en celebración de la primavera que acaba de llegar.

Tom sighed, realizing that the interruption was not going to be resolved quickly. "Let's move away from the road," he suggested, grabbing his backpack. "We'll find a quieter spot to discuss this. Tom glanced back, ensuring they were out of sight, before continuing, "Now, what were we arguing about again?" His attempt at humor was weak, but it was clear that the immediate disturbance had shifted their focus. The real issue, whatever it was, would have to wait until they were far from the road's chaos.

La presencia inesperada de alguien nuevo había cambiado el tono de la conversación, llenándola de una tensión palpable. Tom, sorprendido y un poco irritado por la interrupción, giró lentamente hacia atrás para enfrentar al nuevo venedor. Era una mujer, vestida con una ropa simple pero cuidadosa, sus ojos intensos y determinados mirándolos directamente. "Es importante," continuó ella, "entendernos bien. No hay tiempo para retrasos o miedos. Necesitamos actuar ahora, mientras todavía tenemos la oportunidad." La urgencia en su voz no dejaba lugar a dudas; algo importante estaba en juego, algo que requería de su atención inmediata. Tom, aunque resistente al principio, sintió cómo su postura comenzaba a suavizarse. "Bueno, entonces, cuál es tu propuesta?" preguntó finalmente, abriendo la puerta a una conversación que, sin duda, cambiaría el curso de sus planes. La mujer sonrió, un gesto lleno de confianza, y comenzó a explicar su propuesta, que prometía ser tan peligrosa como emocionante.

es_results_raw: desesperación. "No puedo creer lo que acabas de hacer", continuó, su mirada hundida en mí. La tensión era palpable, cargando el aire con una electricidad cargada de resentimiento y dolor. "¿Cómo puedes ser tan cruel?" preguntó, su voz temblorosa pero llena de un resentimiento creciente. "No mereces amor, no mereces comprensión", sus palabras cortaban como un cuchillo afilado, dejando una herida profunda en mi alma. "Deja de mirarme", exclamó, intentando alejarme de su mirada penetrante. Pero Daisy no estaba dispuesta a liberarme así fácilmente. Se acercó aún más, su mirada incendiaria quemaba mi alma. "Te voy a dejar pensar en lo que has perdido", sus palabras eran un juramento, un anuncio de castigo. "Y cuando te pongas de pie, recordarás este momento como el día en que perdiste todo lo que valía". Con ese ultimátum, se giró abruptamente y salió de la habitación, dejándome atrás con una mezcla de alivio y terror. La puerta se cerró detrás de ella con un golpe, sellando el final de una escena que cambiaría para siempre nuestra relación.

Había visto demasiadas veces cómo el sistema fallaba a aquellos que más lo necesitaban, y había aprendido a cuidar primero a sus pacientes. Aunque el recuerdo de dejar a su paciente allí, vulnerable y solo, seguía con él como una sombra, sabía que había hecho lo correcto. La estacada era un lugar seguro, vigilado, y aunque no era el mejor ambiente para una recuperación, era mejor que dejar a su paciente en manos de un sistema que a menudo se desvía del camino correcto. Ahora, esperaba las pruebas de laboratorio para descubrir la causa subyacente de las síntomas de su paciente. Con la información en mano, podría tomar decisiones informadas y, esperaba, salvar la vida de alguien que tanto necesitaba ayuda. La noche caía pesadamente sobre la ciudad, y el doctor se preguntaba qué sorpresas debo esperar al amanecer.

The crowd fell silent, their curiosity piqued. The person, a librarian by the look of their attire, began to speak, their voice steady and clear. They explained that the book was a rare artifact, a relic from a time long past, and its sudden appearance had caused the disturbance. The librarian went on to describe the book's significance, its contents holding secrets and knowledge long forgotten. As the librarian spoke, the crowd's initial confusion turned into fascination, and a sense of awe filled the air. The incident, which had started with such confusion, ended with a shared moment of enlightenment and appreciation for the power of knowledge. The circle, once a place of disorder, now stood as a testament to the transformative power of learning and discovery.

en_results_raw: George nodded slowly, his mind drifting back to the days when he did attend church. The pews, the hymns, the scent of incense, all seemed like a distant memory now. "Yes, I did," he admitted, his voice barely above a whisper. "It was a different life then. A simpler one, perhaps. But times change, and with them, so do our paths." He paused, gazing out of the window as if trying to catch a glimpse of that past self, standing on the threshold of a church, ready to step into a world of faith and certainty. "I miss that certainty sometimes," he confessed, a hint of longing in his tone. "The church was a place of refuge, of hope. Now, it feels like a relic of a time long gone." His words hung in the air, a testament to the journey he had undertaken since those days, a journey that had led him far from the comforting embrace of faith and into the often harsh reality of the world outside. "But," he added, a determined glint appearing in his eyes, "even without a church, one can still find their own sanctuary. It might not be built of stone and stained glass, but it's there, in the moments of peace and understanding we carve out for ourselves." His reflection turned inward, contemplating the sanctuaries he had built within himself, amidst the chaos of life's journey.

es_results_raw: mirada inquieta se desplazó hacia el horizonte, donde el sol comenzaba a ocultarse. La tarde se tornaba más oscura, reflejando la atmósfera de incertidumbre que envolvía a Gatsby. Con pasos pesados, casi como si cada movimiento lo acercaba más a un destino inevitable, avanzó hacia el agua. El agua del lago reflejaba las últimas luzes del atardecer, creando una atmósfera casi mística. I had committed him to the current of his destiny, and, despite my lingering doubts and the weight of my own moral compass, I could not retract my actions. The sun dipped lower in the sky, casting long shadows over the verdant landscape that had witnessed Gatsby's rise and fall. In the days that followed, I reflected on the events that had transpired, the lives that had been irrevocably altered, and the dreams that had been shattered. Gatsby's grandiose vision of love and wealth had been his undoing, a siren song that lured him into the treacherous waters of obsession and deceit. His end was tragic, yet it was a tragedy of his own making, a testament to the perilous allure of the American Dream. As I navigated the aftermath, grappling with my own role in the drama, I realized that the true measure of a person is not in their grandest ambitions, but in the integrity with which they pursue them. Gatsby's legacy was a cautionary tale, a reminder that the pursuit of dreams must be tempered with wisdom and moral fortitude. In the quietude of retrospection, I understood that the world had not been quite ready for Gatsby, nor he for the world. His light, though it had burned so brightly, had flickered out too soon, leaving behind a void that would never be filled. And in that void, I found myself pondering the nature of love, loss, and the relentless passage of time.

A new white building stood in the middle of the lawn, and when I saw this I understood that my reaction had been entirely accurate. The poor son of God—whether it was that night he leaped on Gatsby’s floating body with a snarl, or that time he killed a man who had found out that he was nephew to von Hindenburg, or any of his varied brutalities in the army or in the world of organized crime—had just committed his third major sin and it would catch up with him as eventually all sins do. It was as if the whole upper part of the egg was broken off from the lower. The East, the successful and luxurious East, had been left behind, and I was standing alone on the gray land—the lone figure of a man in the rain, with a single, solemn dome of a house in the distance. I realized then that I was part of it all, caught up in events that were as inescapable as they were incomprehensible. The green light, the orgiastic future that I had so long associated with Daisy, was suddenly receding. It had retreated back into the past, back into the gray, rain-washed valley of ashes where dreams go to die. And in that moment, I understood the futility of Gatsby’s dream, the impossibility of recapturing the past, and the tragic illusion of believing that one could control destiny through wealth and desire. The American Dream, once so vibrant and full of promise, now lay shattered, a victim of its own excesses and the harsh realities of a world that cared little for the dreams of its inhabitants. The East was no longer a place of hope and opportunity; it was a graveyard of lost illusions, and I, standing in the rain, was its newest mourner.
